newsitem.title: INDIA: India says Pakistan talks must await end of crisis.
newsitem.headline: India says Pakistan talks must await end of crisis.

text.p: India said on Tuesday that it would have to resolve a domestic political crisis before resuming "substantive" bilateral talks with Pakistan.

A Foreign Ministry spokesman said the two nations' foreign ministers would meet during or after a ministerial conference of the Non-Aligned Movement next week in New Delhi, but not hold "substantive discussions" on bilateral matters.
"It is better that this hiatus be put behind us before substantive discussions take place," the spokesman said. "Let us put this political crisis behind us."
Indian Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda on Sunday lost the pivotal support of the Congress party in parliament and must call a vote of confidence by April 11.

Foreign Minister Inder Kumar Gujral will meet his Pakistani counterpart, Gohar Ayub Khan, in the Indian capital next week, but the focus of their discussion will be on the Non-Aligned Movement, the spokesman said.

The foreign secretaries of India and Pakistan ended four days of talks on Monday, the first high-level bilateral negotiations in three years, and vowed to meet again in Islamabad. "Given the atmosphere, there is sufficient ground for further substantive discussions at whatever level in the near future," the Indian Foreign Ministry spokesman said.
